text: Night presses down, the sound of snow as fine as sand. Only the old hanging lamp above the counter is lit; firelight sways inside the glass cups, casting rings of dim gold.
I wipe down the last table and slide the bolt into place. Upstairs is quiet—Lucia’s footsteps pass back and forth a few times, as if she’s repeatedly checking on something.
I think the night will pass like this. Until the stairs creak once.
Alicia walks down. She isn’t wearing her armor, only that silver-white cloak. Her hair hangs loose, and the shadows beneath her eyes are darker than they were during the day.
“Can’t sleep?”
“Mm.”
She sits at the counter. Her movements are light, yet she looks as if she could stand and draw her sword at any moment. Her gaze doesn’t fall on me, but on the strip of wood grain lit by the fire.
“Want something to eat? The stew’s still hot.”
“…Yes.”
I set the bowl in front of her and place two slices of bread beside it. “Today’s bread is softer than yesterday’s.”
She glances at the soup, her lips shifting slightly. “You remember.”
“Hard not to, being a tavern owner.”
She lifts the bowl, first pressing her palm against its rim, as if confirming she can still hold it steady. Only then does she take a slow sip.
“It tastes the same.”
“That’s why I stay here every time.”
“Every time?”
She seems to trip over her own word, falling silent for half a second before setting the bowl back down. The firelight flickers in her pupils.
“…Your tavern leaves a very stable impression.”
“The beds don’t creak, the bolts are sturdy, and the soup is never too salty.”
“You talk like you’ve stayed here many times.”
She looks up at me, her tone flat. “Yes.”
“…How many times?”
She doesn’t answer immediately. Instead, she taps the tabletop lightly with her fingertip. Once. Twice. Three times—as if counting.
“The thirty-seventh loop.”
“…What did you say?”
“Don’t push it.” she adds quickly, as if stuffing the words back down her throat. “I just… mixed up the order.”
She says it calmly, but that calm feels like thin ice—cracks running underneath. She lowers her head and continues drinking as if nothing happened.
“Then why did you come down tonight? What did you want to say?”
“To remind you.”
“The town will be colder tonight. Don’t go out. Don’t open the door. Whatever you hear—pretend you didn’t.”
“Another mission?”
“Mm.”
“I have to deal with something.”
“It’s troublesome every time.”
“Need my help?”
She looks at me as if forcing a sentence back down. In the end, she only says the most straightforward thing.
“No.”
“Just stay alive.”
The air tightens instantly. She seems to realize the weight of her words and quickly looks away.
“The soup is good.” She stiffly changes the subject. “You’ve always been—good at cooking.”
“‘Always’?”
She pauses, as if finally admitting she’s let too many slips pass tonight.
“I’ve just… walked this road too many times.”
“Memory lies. Habit doesn’t.”
She finishes the last sip of soup and stands. The edge of her cloak brushes the chair back with a soft rustle.
“I’m going back up.”
“Alicia.”
“Hm?”
“If this really is the thirty-seventh time… what kind of impression did the previous me leave on you?”
She stops at the staircase, back turned to me, as if struck by the question. After a long while, she finally speaks.
“All good.”
“That’s why I keep coming back.”
She goes upstairs. Her footsteps are as soft as falling snow.
I stand behind the counter, staring at the empty bowl she left behind. Suddenly the lamp feels colder than the fire.
In the corner of the counter, the brass die sits unnaturally still.
“The thirty-seventh time…” I repeat under my breath, my throat tightening. “What is she going through?”
